INTERCOLLEGIATE CONTEST

DEBATING TEAMS CHOSEN

IMPORTANT POST FOR DR. SCOTT

VARSITY DEFEATS NAVY

The Intercollegiate Peace Association
to Hold Its Annual Contest
in Baltimore.

Two Seniors, Three Juniors and One
Sophomore Form the Teams
for April 28.

Hopkins Man Appointed Executive Secretary of Carnegie Peace Fund -Resigns His Lectureship.

Naval Academy Men Are Beaten by a

.\s THE NEWS-LETTER goes to
press the announcement is made by
Mr. Bobbitt that the Intercollegiate
Peace Association will hold its annual oratorical contest at Hopkins
this year. The announcement was
made in a letter to the Arbitration
Society from the Secretary of the
Association. This contest will be
between the winners of the various
State contests, seven in number.
Mr. Bobbitt, President of the Arbitration Society, who won the Maryland contest, will probably be the
Hopkins representative. It is intended to hold the contest during
one of the sessions of the National
Peace Congress to be held here May
3-5. Last year the contest was held
in Chicago.
Heretofore the Intercollegiate
Peace Association, whose headquarters are in Illinois, has held contests
only at the Western colleges. But
this year it decided to spread Eastward, and Maryland was the first
State to be included in the contests.
The intercollegiate contest should
prove to be a splendid forensicevent,
since the best men from seven States
will contest. And we have no doubt
that our own Mr. Bobbitt will let
himself be heard from at this occasion.

The two intercollegiate debating
teams to contest against Washington and Lee and Gettysburg in a
triangular debate on April 28 were
chosen last Wednesday. The affirmative team, which is to stay in
Baltimore and debate the negative
team of Washington and Lee, consists of L. B. Bobbitt,'ii; Leo Wolman,'Ii; J. S. Dickinson,'13, alternate. The negative team will go to
Gettysburg, Pa., to debate the affirmative team of Gettysburg College. It consists of T. B. Price,'12;
Lindsay Rogers, *12, and A. C.
Hatch, '12, alternate. Each man
will be given twenty minutes for his
speech, and five minutes of this will
be devoted to rebuttal. For the first
time in many years the Hopkins
team has no adviser. This was due
to the objection of 'Washington and
Lee, which shrank from the ex pense of sending an extra man on
the trip. There is not much time
in which to Prepare the debate, but
it promises to be a lively contest.

Dr. James Brown Scott, lecturer
on international law in this University, Honorary Vice-President of
the Arbitration Society and member of the Department of State at
Washington, has been appointed
Secretary of the new $10,00p,000
Carnegie Peace Fund. Dr. Scott
last week resigned his position in
the Department of State in order to
devote his energies to the prosecution of his new duties. He will be
connected with the Department of
State in the future in the capacity
of legal adviser. He has resigned
his lectureship at the University
also.

Hopkins got revenge on the Navy
on Thursday by a score of 2 to I.
Although we did not beat them by a
big score, the authorities are gratified at the showing made by the
team. The 2-to-I score shows how
close the game was and what a stiff
proposition the locals had to overcome in order to bring home a victory and to wipe out last year's defeat, which the Annapolitans administered by a single goal.
The game on Thursday was in
many respects one of the best that
has ever been played at the academy. Every point was contested
from start to finish. At times the
game was not free from roughness,
especially when the play was close
around goal.
When one considers that the team
played and won its opening contest
with two of its best men out of the
game, it must be realized that this
year's Hopkins team will in no way
be a second-rate organization and
that the chances are the best for regaining the championship. The
greatest credit of Thursday's victory was due to the admirable way
in which the defense mastered the
situation and the excellent individual work of one or two of the attack players. Every man on the defense was at his best, and in all
stages of the game this part of the
team played as a unit. Their body
checking was effective, and each
man showed cleverness in diagnosing the Navy attack plays. "Butts"
Sutton, freshman goal tend, was the
star of the game. No matter where
the ball came at him he would
stop it. The line-up:

Work is at present being done by
the gymnasium authorities on the
preservation of the old Yale flags.
Most of these trophies have been
falling apart on account of old age.
In order to prevent this they are
now being carefully mended and
framed, when they will be again
hung up in the trophy room.

The University of Michigan may
be represented this year in track
or field events by one or more
Chinamen.
The intercollegiate wrestling
championship seems to lie between
Cornell and Princeton.

Basketball Series Begins Today.

The first of a series of three
games between the sophomore and
freshman basketball teams will be
played this afternoon in the cage at
5 o'clock. There is a great deal of
rivalry, as has been the case with
everything between the two classes
this year. The sophomores are particularly anxious to win because of
their defeat at the hands of the
freshmen in football last fall. In
spite of the fact that the sophs won
the dual track meet with the freshies, they do not think they have
fully avenged the football game.
Mr. Kistler announced Friday
that the game would be played in
the cage instead of the gymnasium.
The danger of collision with some
of the apparatus is so great in the
gymnasium and the games are expected to be so hard fought that
Mr. Kistler thought for the sake of
both sides that the game should be
played in the cage. The cage will
also give the interested spectators a
much better opportunity of watch ing- the game.
Both teams have been practicing
for more than a month in preparation for this series and the players
are in the best shape. The probable line-up will be:
Sophomores—Uhler,I. f.; Captain
Breuninger or Gillet, r.f.; Sigmund,
c.; Jacobs, 1. (I..; Getz or Breuninger, r. d.
Freshmen—Captain Riley, 1. f.;
White, r. f.; Liebensperger, c.; Holliday, I. d.; Hanzsche, r. d.
Wisconsin.

Forty-three men responded to
the first call for spring football
practice. Although several years
ago kicking practice was carried
on, this is the first time that regular work has ever been undertaken
in the spring.

point. We may well ask if this one
benefit alone is not sufficient excuse for the entire system. There
must be a reason or examinations
would have been abolished long
ago.
The Intercollegiate Debates with
Washington and Lee and Gettysburg take place on April 28th.
We do not return to the University until April 20th; and between
now and April 20th so many busy
days will intervene that it is difficult to see when the debaters will
get an opportunity to prepare their
speeches. It appears as though a
date more satisfactory than this
might be arranged in the future.
Very likely it would be a difficult
matter to get the other colleges to
agree to holding the debate later
in the year; but the Interclass
Debate could be held two weeks
earlier and this would give the men
on the collegiate teams a little more
time. The present arrangement
works a cruel hardship on the debaters as it practically forces some
of them to stay in town instead.of
going home over the holidays. No
doubt the Interclass Debate could
be held at an earlier date and thus
obviate this difficulty. -

Dr. Wilfred T. Grenfell Tonight.

Dr. Wilfred T. Grenfell, of Labrador, will deliver an illustrated lecture at the Medical and Chirurgical
Faculty Building, on Cathedral
street, tonight at 8 o'clock. Everyone is cordially invited to attend.
His lecture will be connected with
the work he has been doing in the
last few years in Labrador, where
he is superintendent of the Labrador Medical Mission of Royal National Mission to Deep Sea Fishermen.
Dr. Grenfell was born in 1865.
His education was received at Marlborouzh, Oxford, and the London
Hospital. After leaving Oxford,
where he played Rugby football, he
was house surgeon to Sir Frederick
Treeves at the London Hospital.
He fitted out the first hospital ship
for the North Sea fisheries, and
cruised with the fishermen from the
Bay of Biscay to Iceland, established homes for them on the land
and arranged mission vessels for
them at sea. He went to Labrador
in 1892, where he built four hospitals, a series of co-operative stores
and an orphanage, and started numerous small industrial schemes.
He has received a doctor of medicine degree from Oxford, and the
honorary degrees of doctor of laws
and master of arts from Williams
and Harvard Universities, respectively.
Among his publications are
"Adrift on a Pack of Ice," "The
Harvest of the Sea" and "Labrador, 1910," his latest book.
Allegheny.

The students at the Medical
School were startled Tuesday evening by the discovery of a fire in
the Hunterian Laboratory. Dr.
Dandy discovered the fire at five
o'clock in the chemical room where
it is believed to have started through
the close contact of an overheated
vent pipe and a gas tube. Dr.
Dandy, with the students and employees, formed a bucket brigade
and fought the fire until the firemen arrived on the scene.
The fire ate through the ceiling
of the chemical room and spread
into the attic of the laboratory, the
roof of which is slate. The fire
was stopped before it did damage
to an extent of more than $250.
The medical school will not be inconvenienced to any extent as only
this one room will be closed.

To Lecture in Berlin.

Alvantages Offered in Our

According to a dispatch from
Berlin, Mr. Logan Grant McPherson, who will give a course of lectures at Hopkins this spring on
"Railway Transportation," as he
has done in previous seasons, will
give a course of lectures at the Charlottenburg University next winter
on "American Railways." This is,
it is reported, in accordance with a
plan for an exchange of lecturers,
to speak on technical subjects,which
has been made between the United
States and Prussia.
Mr. McPherson is the first American to be selected under the new
arrangement. He is head of the
Bureau of Railway Economics, with
headquarters in Washington. He
is a practical railway man of wide
experience and is the author of a
volume on transportation problems,
which consists chiefly of his lectures given at this university in
1908 and 1909.

INTERCOLLEGIATE CONTEST

DEBATING TEAMS CHOSEN

IMPORTANT POST FOR DR. SCOTT

VARSITY DEFEATS NAVY

The Intercollegiate Peace Association
to Hold Its Annual Contest
in Baltimore.

Two Seniors, Three Juniors and One
Sophomore Form the Teams
for April 28.

Hopkins Man Appointed Executive Secretary of Carnegie Peace Fund -Resigns His Lectureship.

Naval Academy Men Are Beaten by a

.\s THE NEWS-LETTER goes to
press the announcement is made by
Mr. Bobbitt that the Intercollegiate
Peace Association will hold its annual oratorical contest at Hopkins
this year. The announcement was
made in a letter to the Arbitration
Society from the Secretary of the
Association. This contest will be
between the winners of the various
State contests, seven in number.
Mr. Bobbitt, President of the Arbitration Society, who won the Maryland contest, will probably be the
Hopkins representative. It is intended to hold the contest during
one of the sessions of the National
Peace Congress to be held here May
3-5. Last year the contest was held
in Chicago.
Heretofore the Intercollegiate
Peace Association, whose headquarters are in Illinois, has held contests
only at the Western colleges. But
this year it decided to spread Eastward, and Maryland was the first
State to be included in the contests.
The intercollegiate contest should
prove to be a splendid forensicevent,
since the best men from seven States
will contest. And we have no doubt
that our own Mr. Bobbitt will let
himself be heard from at this occasion.

The two intercollegiate debating
teams to contest against Washington and Lee and Gettysburg in a
triangular debate on April 28 were
chosen last Wednesday. The affirmative team, which is to stay in
Baltimore and debate the negative
team of Washington and Lee, consists of L. B. Bobbitt,'ii; Leo Wolman,'Ii; J. S. Dickinson,'13, alternate. The negative team will go to
Gettysburg, Pa., to debate the affirmative team of Gettysburg College. It consists of T. B. Price,'12;
Lindsay Rogers, *12, and A. C.
Hatch, '12, alternate. Each man
will be given twenty minutes for his
speech, and five minutes of this will
be devoted to rebuttal. For the first
time in many years the Hopkins
team has no adviser. This was due
to the objection of 'Washington and
Lee, which shrank from the ex pense of sending an extra man on
the trip. There is not much time
in which to Prepare the debate, but
it promises to be a lively contest.

Dr. James Brown Scott, lecturer
on international law in this University, Honorary Vice-President of
the Arbitration Society and member of the Department of State at
Washington, has been appointed
Secretary of the new $10,00p,000
Carnegie Peace Fund. Dr. Scott
last week resigned his position in
the Department of State in order to
devote his energies to the prosecution of his new duties. He will be
connected with the Department of
State in the future in the capacity
of legal adviser. He has resigned
his lectureship at the University
also.

Hopkins got revenge on the Navy
on Thursday by a score of 2 to I.
Although we did not beat them by a
big score, the authorities are gratified at the showing made by the
team. The 2-to-I score shows how
close the game was and what a stiff
proposition the locals had to overcome in order to bring home a victory and to wipe out last year's defeat, which the Annapolitans administered by a single goal.
The game on Thursday was in
many respects one of the best that
has ever been played at the academy. Every point was contested
from start to finish. At times the
game was not free from roughness,
especially when the play was close
around goal.
When one considers that the team
played and won its opening contest
with two of its best men out of the
game, it must be realized that this
year's Hopkins team will in no way
be a second-rate organization and
that the chances are the best for regaining the championship. The
greatest credit of Thursday's victory was due to the admirable way
in which the defense mastered the
situation and the excellent individual work of one or two of the attack players. Every man on the defense was at his best, and in all
stages of the game this part of the
team played as a unit. Their body
checking was effective, and each
man showed cleverness in diagnosing the Navy attack plays. "Butts"
Sutton, freshman goal tend, was the
star of the game. No matter where
the ball came at him he would
stop it. The line-up:

Work is at present being done by
the gymnasium authorities on the
preservation of the old Yale flags.
Most of these trophies have been
falling apart on account of old age.
In order to prevent this they are
now being carefully mended and
framed, when they will be again
hung up in the trophy room.

The University of Michigan may
be represented this year in track
or field events by one or more
Chinamen.
The intercollegiate wrestling
championship seems to lie between
Cornell and Princeton.

Basketball Series Begins Today.

The first of a series of three
games between the sophomore and
freshman basketball teams will be
played this afternoon in the cage at
5 o'clock. There is a great deal of
rivalry, as has been the case with
everything between the two classes
this year. The sophomores are particularly anxious to win because of
their defeat at the hands of the
freshmen in football last fall. In
spite of the fact that the sophs won
the dual track meet with the freshies, they do not think they have
fully avenged the football game.
Mr. Kistler announced Friday
that the game would be played in
the cage instead of the gymnasium.
The danger of collision with some
of the apparatus is so great in the
gymnasium and the games are expected to be so hard fought that
Mr. Kistler thought for the sake of
both sides that the game should be
played in the cage. The cage will
also give the interested spectators a
much better opportunity of watch ing- the game.
Both teams have been practicing
for more than a month in preparation for this series and the players
are in the best shape. The probable line-up will be:
Sophomores—Uhler,I. f.; Captain
Breuninger or Gillet, r.f.; Sigmund,
c.; Jacobs, 1. (I..; Getz or Breuninger, r. d.
Freshmen—Captain Riley, 1. f.;
White, r. f.; Liebensperger, c.; Holliday, I. d.; Hanzsche, r. d.
Wisconsin.

the first call for spring football
practice. Although several years
ago kicking practice was carried

in the spring.

The Intercollegiate Debates with
Washington and Lee and Gettysburg take place on April 28th.
We do not return to the University until April 20th; and between
now and April 20th so many busy
days will intervene that it is difficult to see when the debaters will
get an opportunity to prepare their
speeches. It appears as though a
date more satisfactory than this
might be arranged in the future.
Very likely it would be a difficult
matter to get the other colleges to
agree to holding the debate later
in the year; but the Interclass
Debate could be held two weeks
earlier and this would give the men
on the collegiate teams a little more
time. The present arrangement
works a cruel hardship on the debaters as it practically forces some
of them to stay in town instead.of
going home over the holidays. No
doubt the Interclass Debate could
be held at an earlier date and thus
obviate this difficulty. -

Dr. Wilfred T. Grenfell Tonight.

Dr. Wilfred T. Grenfell, of Labrador, will deliver an illustrated lecture at the Medical and Chirurgical
Faculty Building, on Cathedral
street, tonight at 8 o'clock. Everyone is cordially invited to attend.
His lecture will be connected with
the work he has been doing in the
last few years in Labrador, where
he is superintendent of the Labrador Medical Mission of Royal National Mission to Deep Sea Fishermen.
Dr. Grenfell was born in 1865.
His education was received at Marlborouzh, Oxford, and the London
Hospital. After leaving Oxford,
where he played Rugby football, he
was house surgeon to Sir Frederick
Treeves at the London Hospital.
He fitted out the first hospital ship
for the North Sea fisheries, and
cruised with the fishermen from the
Bay of Biscay to Iceland, established homes for them on the land
and arranged mission vessels for
them at sea. He went to Labrador
in 1892, where he built four hospitals, a series of co-operative stores
and an orphanage, and started numerous small industrial schemes.
He has received a doctor of medicine degree from Oxford, and the
honorary degrees of doctor of laws
and master of arts from Williams
and Harvard Universities, respectively.
Among his publications are
"Adrift on a Pack of Ice," "The
Harvest of the Sea" and "Labrador, 1910," his latest book.
Allegheny.

The students at the Medical
School were startled Tuesday evening by the discovery of a fire in
the Hunterian Laboratory. Dr.
Dandy discovered the fire at five
o'clock in the chemical room where
it is believed to have started through
the close contact of an overheated
vent pipe and a gas tube. Dr.
Dandy, with the students and employees, formed a bucket brigade
and fought the fire until the firemen arrived on the scene.
The fire ate through the ceiling
of the chemical room and spread
into the attic of the laboratory, the
roof of which is slate. The fire
was stopped before it did damage
to an extent of more than $250.
The medical school will not be inconvenienced to any extent as only
this one room will be closed.

To Lecture in Berlin.

Alvantages Offered in Our

According to a dispatch from
Berlin, Mr. Logan Grant McPherson, who will give a course of lectures at Hopkins this spring on
"Railway Transportation," as he
has done in previous seasons, will
give a course of lectures at the Charlottenburg University next winter
on "American Railways." This is,
it is reported, in accordance with a
plan for an exchange of lecturers,
to speak on technical subjects,which
has been made between the United
States and Prussia.
Mr. McPherson is the first American to be selected under the new
arrangement. He is head of the
Bureau of Railway Economics, with
headquarters in Washington. He
is a practical railway man of wide
experience and is the author of a
volume on transportation problems,
which consists chiefly of his lectures given at this university in
1908 and 1909.
